benchmark_details.name: Reasoning Grasping Benchmark
benchmark_details.overview: The Reasoning Grasping Benchmark measures robot performance in generating grasp poses based on implicit instructions from human users. It includes various object and part grasping scenarios derived from the GraspNet-1 billion dataset, enhanced with reasoning instructions.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To advance robotic systems' ability to interpret implicit human commands and generate appropriate grasping actions.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The model struggles with novel objects not seen during training.

data.source: Extended GraspNet-1 billion dataset with reasoning instructions.
data.size: 1,730 reasoning instructions, 64 objects, 109 parts, approximately 100 million grasping poses
data.annotation: Manual segmentation of parts and automated generation of reasoning instructions.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on the intersection over union (IoU) score and the angular deviation of predicted grasp poses compared to ground truth.
methodology.interpretation: Higher precision in grasping indicates better model performance in understanding implicit instructions.
methodology.baseline_results: The model outperformed baseline methods including CLIP and LLaV A models in grasping prediction tasks.
methodology.validation: The benchmark was validated through extensive real-world experiments with human instructions.
